Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 196.20, down 5 (-2.49%), High: 198.00, Low: 195.00, Volume: 8.42m

11:09 am
BE

PM

(BBOC -- you would have thought so)

PM

11:09 am

PM

PM

11:10 am
BE

.... But Unilever has stopped supplying Tesco. That's the reason it's about Tesco.

PM

Yeah sure

BE

To state the obvious. Obviously.

11:10 am
BE

Go ahead. Give us Clive's thoughts.

PM

FOOD TECTONICS - The UK pricing battles begin with sterling weakness and it's a
heavyweight one Tesco vs. Unilever

PM

The UK-EU Referendum is having progressively more economic consequences, centred upon sterling. The currency
was also going to be the key mechanism to determine how domestic and international markets viewed Britain's
decision to leave the Union. Roughly four months on the wheels did not fall off the UK's economic bus, albeit sterling
has depreciated between 15-20% against the US dollar and the euro.
Importing inflation
Many commentators, ourselves included, have said since the Referendum outcome that the UK will be importing
inflation if sterling weakness persists; it has been a case of 'when' not 'if'. Key factors influencing the process are the
source of goods, the domestic vs., foreign constituents of goods, prevalent commercial hedging and the competitive
dynamics within a market. In this respect, perhaps the most rapid response market is crude oil, priced in dollars,
which is now feeding into rising prices on the forecourts of the UK.

11:10 am
PM

Heavyweight clash
Within such a context, we noted the bristling bush Telegraph last evening (12th October 2016) as The Guardian
broke a story that a spat has erupted between two giants of the British food scene, Tesco# (TSCO, Hold) and
Unilever^ (ULVR, Buy), the latter reporting quarterly results today (13th October 2016) - see separate Shore Capital
research for an update on that. In an apparent disagreement over the supplier's desire for price recovery, seemingly
currency derived, Tesco is resisting Unilever's requests which is, apparently leading to a cutting off of supply, a work
down of stocks and the prospect of empty shelves in the near future of key lines such as Comfort, Flora and
Marmite, the latter a firm favourite of the author.

PM

Common sense to prevail...
We shall watch with interest to see how matters pan out, albeit Tesco needs Unilever products and Unilever needs to
distribute through the UK's largest store and online distribution channel. Hence, we sense an agreement will be
thrashed out in due course. What is clear though is that cost recovery is going to be a little more challenging in this
present round than it has been in recent years, very much more difficult than the halcyon days of the late 'noughties'
for suppliers, when they could more often than not implement price rises at will, support volumes through promotions
and keep the supermarket happy through 'commercial income'.

PM

The supermarket world has changed...
Hmmm. Such dynamics certainly helped manufacturers' margins, particularly international proprietary brand players.
However, such dynamics were a key process in the supermarkets becoming detached from their customers, a
detachment that let the limited assortment discounters (LADs) into the UK and so fundamentally adjusted the
competitive scene in the domestic supermarket industry. As such, the price of the superstores' sleeping at the wheel
and becoming effectively supplier led has been a collapse in margins, asset write-down and management change.

11:11 am
PM

...no going back to free lunch for the discounters
For much of the last three to four years the UK supermarkets have been trying to repair the damage of collective
near commercial suicide. Through heavy margin depletion the pricing differential between the absolute supermarkets
and the LADs has been systematically narrowing, work that is now showing some positive effect with rising volumes
and improving same store sales. Accordingly, with proprietary brands being key lines differentiating supermarkets
from LADs, it is understandable that there is going to be resistance to wholesale price rises, particularly of the sort so
evident in the last decade; noting that promotional participation is on the decline and commercial relationships have
been brutally simplified.

BE

Cripes. There's a lot of that.

PM

That's v interesting on the discounters

11:11 am
PM

Yeah, but Clive is comprehensive thumbs up

PM

As such, we sense that the retailer's will be more systematic and analytical in their consideration of price change,
noting that they cannot defy gravity, particularly a force so evident as a material currency movement. In this respect,
whilst seeking analysis on the source of costs, the steps to mitigate those costs and an appraisal of the competitive
dynamics, i.e. prevalent balance between supply and demand, we do expect to see price movements, noting that
supermarkets tend to 'prefer' few movements rather than many small steps.

PM

Just two more!

11:12 am
PM

Highly symbolic connection
The 'battle' between Tesco and Unilever, therefore, is highly symbolic but also symptomatic of what we deem to be a
potentially turbulent period for supplier-retailer relationships; relationships now set within the context of greater
regularity scrutiny in the UK too. Commercial negotiations by product segment will also include potential drives for
import substitution, boosting some domestic suppliers as a challenge to imports and, possibly, rising exports, should
international demand draw product from the UK with the currency derived competitiveness. Importers will also be
taking views on their pricing strategy for the UK, set against broad market dynamics.

PM

UK food deflation is set to ease...
In general we believe that the outcome of all this will be easing food deflation and the growing possibility of inflation
in CY2017. With UK wages and salaries set to be modest, we foresee rising CPI, partially fuelled by food, as
depleting rising living standards, making value all the more important to the shopper. Elasticities will, therefore, be an
increasingly important feature of pricing and demand (volume) features for the UK food chain. The supermarket will
be, as it has for many decades, the arbiter between an efficient and effective supply chain and their shoppers to our
minds. How this pans out will be important for the financial outcome of all concerned; we sense that shoppers will be
paying some of the price of sterling weakness in forthcoming quarters.
If you like Marmite on your toast, nip to the supermarket now...

PM

I hate Marmite.

11:13 am
PM

PM

PM

11:13 am
PM

BE

BE

11:14 am
BE

Anyway, have Bruno at Bernstein as well.

BE

Who's a lot briefer than Clive.

BE

Tesco has typically 1-2 weeks' stock, so availability will deteriorate; some products are temporarily delisted online.

This is inevitable Brexit induced inflation. While politicians can deny reality, a shampoo produced on the continent is now 17% more expensive.

This is retail-supplier negotiation 101. It's the supplier's role to pass on increased cost and it is retailer's job to challenge price increases. It happens all the time and in the end they settle for what seems a fair cost allocation. However, those discussions rarely spill open in public and rarely lead to de-listings. Clearly the scale of the negotiation is much bigger than usual, but so is the event. Brexit-sized events are rare. This is such a large event that it may simply be that the 2 gorillas on both sides have decided to go through the motions of the negotiation on behalf of the industry. This isn't about Tesco or Unilever but about all UK retailers & suppliers.

11:15 am
BE

Retailers won't absorb this inflation for 4 reasons: (1) Consumers are much better able to deal with inflation through switching from A brand into B brand and private label. (2) Consumers have never spent so little on food: 12.1% of disposable income, an all-time low, a pre-cursor for previous inflation increases, (3) Starting point of -2% deflation pre-Brexit makes it easier to go from -2% to +3% then if the starting point would have been +4%. (4) Margin compression has historically never depended on absolute level of inflation.

BE

Food retail valuations move with food inflation: for every 1% food inflation change, sector valuations change by 4-5%. We rate Tesco Outperform with PT of £2.20.

PM

Yeah, this is a key point

11:16 am
PM

Inflation is actually good for grocers

PM

BE

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,625, down 99 (-2.66%), High: 3,689, Low: 3,622, Volume: 2.12m

11:18 am
BE

Unilever has reported 3Q16 sales with organic growth of 3.2%, vs.
consensus (company-compiled) at 2.9% and our 3.1%. However, the beat
was entirely driven by pricing, with pricing growth of 3.6% (consensus
2.2%) and volume of -0.4% (consensus +0.6%), driven by higher pricing in
EMs. The volume decline is Unilever’s first since 4Q14 and EM growth of
5.6% was the weakest since 1Q15.
Growth in the quarter was largely driven by the lower-margin parts of
Unilever’s product mix, with Refreshment growing fastest (4.5%, 2015 EBIT
margin 8.3%), followed by Home Care (3.9% growth, 7.3% margin),
Personal Care (3.1% growth, 18.1% margin) and Foods (1.7% growth,
17.8% margin) and therefore is likely margin-dilutive.

BE

Management commented that consumer demand has remained weak and
is reflected in the negative volume development.
The FY outlook for volume growth ahead of the market and steady
improvement in core operating margin was reiterated; consensus expects
FY16 organic growth of 4%.
Today’s announcement and small beat implies only modest changes to
consensus.

BE

They're sellers.

11:18 am
BE

We are Sell-rated on Unilever (both the NV and the PLC) driven by our
expectation of slowing EM growth, deflationary pricing pressure in DMs,
coupled with rising local competition and the rise of e-commerce, though
we are encouraged by Unilever’s proactive steps to position itself to
compete within this growing channel. Given these structural headwinds,
we do not think the current 12-month forward P/E (a 25% premium (on
I/B/E/S consensus) to its 10-year average multiple) is justified, despite it
becoming increasingly focused on cost savings and margin delivery .

BE

And Caz, off the call.

BE

Post the Q316 call, we do not expect consensus numbers to change for FY16 but clearly pressure is mounting on FY17, as we see low single digit pressure to company-compiled consensus from slower LFL. Admittedly, many of the challenges will be faced by the sector as well (slower growth, RM challenges, pricing pressure) but today’s results show Unilever is not immune. For FY16, management sees c4% LFL and 30-40bps margin (aligned with consensus), but we think hitting the 4.4% LFL consensus in FY17 is looking challenging in the context of the deteriorating demand. Coming out of Q316 earnings, we believe Unilever should still look better placed within the sector, but we continue to expect a tough reporting season, staying cautious on the sector

11:20 am
BE

Key highlights from the call: 1) a more challenging and volatile demand environment – volumes flat in aggregate, but down in EMs and likely to remain under pressure; 2) Asia volumes pressure to last several quarters until pricing is through the system, pricing driven by raw materials with palm oil up 70% YTD, crude oil up 50%; 3) volumes in LA likely to get worse before they get better, expect volumes to turn positive through FY17 with lower price; 4) Europe: see less pricing pressure and happy with performance in the USA; and 5) cost savings on track (ZBB, Connected for Growth) without additonal upside as management guidance is for 30-40bps FY16 margin, aligned with consensus.

BE

Coo -- palm oil's up 70% year to date. Missed that.

BE

We rate Unilever Overweight. We see two key drivers turning more positive for the company, namely top-line momentum and margin expansion. We expect FY16 EPS growth aligned with the Food/HPC average despite higher FX headwinds than peers, and HSD EPS growth thereafter. In terms of top line, we forecast 4% LFL in FY16, aligned with most peers. We now see a case for acceleration in the margin delivery to the tune of c40-50bps pa (vs 30bps pa delivered over the past four years) as Unilever rolls out ZBB (zero-based budgeting) models to rein in overhead costs, along with its continued work on improving profitability in Household Care and Ice Cream.

11:24 am
Standard Life PLC (SL.:LSE): Last: 332.20, down 16.7 (-4.79%), High: 342.00, Low: 329.90, Volume: 4.08m
BE

Standard Life’s flagship fund, Global Absolute Return Strategies (GARS), has been
an impressive success story for Standard Life, driving the majority of net inflows for
the past six years. However, the fund’s performance has been poor over the past 18
months, and this has started to drive outflows. We have seen similar experience at
flagship funds at both Henderson’s and M&G (owned by Pru plc), where earnings
estimates have declined 10% and 20% respectively. We believe the GARS outflows
could persist through the remainder of the year and through 2017, and we reduce
our forward estimates for Standard Life by up to 5%. With 14% downside to our
revised target price of 301p, we are downgrading our rating to Underweight, and
prefer Prudential plc, our Top Pick on the sector. As we discussed in our note
“Prudential plc – Inflection point”, 8 Sep 16, Prudential faced similar issues with
M&G over the past 18 months, but we believe we are now at an inflection point, with
its flagship fund, the Optimal Income Fund, having net inflows for the past three
consecutive months.

BE

SLI a success story, driven by GARS - Standard Life Investments (SLI) has been a
significant success story for Standard Life, and we expect it to contribute more than
50% of group earnings in 2016. The success has been driven primarily by multi asset
AUM (primarily GARS), which have increased to £50bn of AUM as at June 2016. GARS
flows have represented over 50% of net flows since 2010, including 92% in 2015.

11:24 am
BE

...however performance disappointing – GARS performance has been poor for the
past 18 months, and is down in absolute terms since peaking in April 2015. The fund
has underperformed its closest peers Aviva AIMS and Invesco GTR, and more
importantly, is now underperforming its target (LIBOR +5%) over a 12 month, 3 year
and 5 year period.

BE

...and starting to impact flows – The performance issues have started to impact flows.
Flows were positive in H1, but this was largely driven by strong January flows.
According to data from Bloomberg GARS has been in outflows for the past five months,
with the net outflows increasing to c£500m in August.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 851.00, down 13.5 (-1.56%), High: 884.00, Low: 850.50, Volume: 1.71m
BE

BE

BE

BE

11:35 am
BE

Revs +5% y/y LFL, at the low-end 5%-7% FY guidance. Sky points to temporary
factors and reiterates outlook. Silence on key metrics such as churn (recently
deteriorating in the UK) and UK BB adds (which dropped 75% between 1H and
2H15/16) should raise concern. Mgmt confident that higher box/install costs
from making Sky Q the mainstream UK product can be recovered. We think one
approach will be to convert Q homes to Sky BB, a concern for BT.

BE

Silence on key metrics: churn and BB adds. Sky had indicated that disclosure in today's
1Q16/17 update would be reduced relative to previous 1Q/3Q results. Nonetheless, the
absence of some key metrics that we believe it is necessary to see to properly comprehend
trading performance should be a concern. In particular, we highlight the lack of churn
disclosure. For a business such as Sky UK, which drives rev growth primarily through
raising price (in return for consistent product upgrades), churn is a crucial indicator of how
customers are reacting. It is sensitive right now in that UK churn (which had been coming
down) has started to rise in the last 3 quarters (from 9.8% Sep 2015 to 11.2% Jun 2016).
Sky's latest TV price rise took effect from early June, so a Sept 2016 churn figure could
have supported mgmt.'s statement on this morning's call that the increase landed well.
BB growth slowed abruptly last year: from 277k in 1H15/16 to 70k in 2H, with only 24k
added in the final quarter. A credible concern is that Sky's BB growth will be squeezed from
Vodafone's consumer BB offer gaining market presence and Virgin's network expansion.

BE

UK. 1Q16/17 revenue growth of 5% was in-line with FY15/16 but slightly below our FY16/17 target (7.3%). The balance of the year should be boosted by mobile (due to launch before Dec). Management also noted that the UK advertising market was weak in 1Q (with Sky advertising revs -3% y/y) although it did not go so far as to guide for advertising rev recovery. Retail customer net adds of 35% (down from 77k 1Q15/16) was attributed to a lack of Olympics coverage and marketing being focused on new innovations.

11:36 am
BE

Germany. 1Q revs +9% y/y (const. fx), similar to the 9.6% in 1Q15/16. We model +9.5%
LFL in FY16/17. Retail customer growth slowed to 49k in Q1 (+94k in 1Q15/16). Mgmt.
highlighted Olympics impact particularly heavy in Germany as it delayed the launch of the
Bundesliga. It also suggested that in quarters of ‘high innovation’ (Sky launched Sky Ticket/
UHD) this focus tends to result in slower subscriber growth. Finally, we understand that in
July, marketing was overly focused on marketing box sets, which had a negative impact on
trading, according to mgmt. this had been corrected by the end of the quarter.
Italy. 1Q revs +13% y/y (const. fx), but +4% LFL , consolidating strengthening trends last
year (+5% LFL in 4Q15/16). We model growth of +2.0% LFL in FY16/17. Retail customer
base +22k (-37k in 1Q15/16). Mgmt. said that Italy was trading better than UK/Germany,
highlighting the success of its free to air channel TV8 and the positive contribution from Euro
2016. In the release, Sky said that over 50% of customers are now connected and able to
access Sky On Demand, impressive given the relatively low levels of broadband penetration.

BE

Sky not as cheap as it looks. Sky trades on 15.1x/12.6x PE Jun 2017/18 vs SXXP
15.0x/13.4x. But unadjusted headline multiples overlook the effect of Sky Q boxes being
capitalised (and amortised over up to 7 years) where UK Sky+ boxes were expensed upfront.
This accounting was widely discussed after the FY results in July. Back then, however, Sky
was providing specific assurance that Q boxes would only be deployed in small volume this
year. Now that Sky Q is being expanded to mass-market volume, the boost to net income
will be material. If Q boxes were expensed (as BT does), Sky would trade on 17.7x/14.0x.
And net debt-to-EBITDA in Jun 2017 would be 3.2x (instead of 2.9x).

BE

That's Jerry Dellis, of course.

11:37 am
BE

BE

BE

Sky’s 1Q17 revenues were solid and management states several times in the release
that the business is on track against full year expectations, which we interpret as
consensus is well underpinned. We leave our forecasts unchanged. We see next
week’s investor day as a bigger catalyst. With investors ignoring management’s
story of superior growth through multi products sale and new initiatives, as
evidenced by the underperformance this year, we believe that Sky would benefit
from unveiling financial targets. A range of revenue growth for each country, an
indication of programming costs as a percentage of revenues and a guide for other
costs as a percentage of revenues would be very welcome. That would enable
investors to calculate an EBITA range for say 2019E at the end of the current Premier
League cycle and re-assure on numbers. Re-iterate Overweight with 1,000p target.

WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,580, up 55 (+3.61%), High: 1,599, Low: 1,537, Volume: 224.87k
11:44 am
PM

RBC big fans of this, it seems

PM

WH Smith remains one of our Best Ideas in General Retail for exposure to strong global travel trends, active space management, favourable mix impacts on margin and ongoing cost savings and cash returns (additional £50mn share buyback announced today).

PM

Richard Chamberlain

11:45 am
PM

Our view: Outperform, 2000p price objective

We favour WH Smith for a) Its strong Travel rollout story b) further High Street gross margin upside, c) its strong cost saving culture, c) its strong track record of cash returns, and d) its rating of 14x CY17E P/E with a 3% dividend yield and £50mn share buyback, we think this makes a strong case for owing the shares and we reiterate our Outperform rating with a £20 price target.

BE

11:46 am
PM

11:46 am
BE

PM

BE

11:47 am
BE

BE

BE

11:49 am
BE

Have Canaccord.

BE

WH Smith delivered a 7% increase in Headline PBT to £132m, in line with Reuters
consensus forecasts. The full year dividend was lifted by 11% to 43.9p (slightly ahead of
consensus, but in line with CGe of 44.0p). Group LFL was +1%, the first full year positive
LFL figure at group level for well over 15 years, which is a noteworthy achievement.
In terms of group profit growth, the main driver of momentum in absolute terms remains
the Travel division, with a 9% or £7m increase to £87m (CGe: £87m). Within this,
International Travel continues to grow at a greater rate from its smaller base, with a sales
increase of 39% to £79m (with LFL growth of 8% vs the total Travel division figure of
+4%) and profits rising to £7m from £5m last year.
This said, the High Street division also weighed in with a greater than traditional increase
(of £1m - £2m), with a £3m or 5% increase to £62m (CGe: £62m). An additional £2m
of cost savings were realised in H2, bringing the FY16 total back to the original target of
£11m. A further £10m of cost savings has been identified for the coming three years,
bringing the total to £19m, of which £10m is to be delivered in FY17.

BE

Product category LFL sales and gross margin (GM) progression were as follows at the
group level: Stationery +3% (GM -30bps), News & Impulse flat (GM +130bps) and Books
-2% (GM +130bps). We expect further gross margin progression to be achieved in FY17.
Cash generation remains strong with free cash flow of £108m, and the fixed charge
cover nudged up to 1.7x from 1.6x last year. Reflecting the opportunities ahead,
including the relocation of up to a further 61 Post Offices into its stores (of which 19
have been completed), capex for FY17 is to be c £48m, vs £42m in FY16, with an
anticipated run rate of around £40m thereafter.

11:50 am
BE

Impact on our view
WH Smith has delivered another year to its impressive record of profit growth and
cash generation. While its Travel division tends to grab the headlines given the delta
of its contribution to group operating profit growth (£m), along with the higher top
and bottom line growth rates (%), the High Street division has relentlessly ground out
profit growth (and cash generation) for well over 10 years. Both divisions continue to
deliver gross margin improvements, and the High Street division continues to uncover
and realise cost savings. The biggest potential risk we see is to Travel, should falling
consumer confidence and economic weakening post Brexit translate into reduced
passenger numbers. Even so, this will be mitigated by continued growth in Travel outlets,
domestically and internationally.

BE

Valuation
The shares continue to trade at a premium to the wider sector on a cal 16E PER of 15.6x
falling to 14.5x for cal 17E. The corresponding EV/EBITDA metrics are 10.2x and 9.8x.
The PER ratings equate to around a 15% premium to the wider sector, reflecting the
group's prospects within Travel and consistency of cash generation.

11:52 am
PM

All things considered, Q3 2016 was a good one for Kenmare. Excavated ore and grade were slightly down on Q2 2016, but production of finished products was a quarterly record due to improved Mineral Separation Plant (MSP) operating times: ilmenite, zircon and rutile production were 12%, 17% and 32% up, respectively.

PM

Kenmare believes that Moma is “on track” to achieve record finished production output for the full year, with cash operating costs expected to be at the lower end of guidance. That said, Kenmare also issued updated guidance today, and we are unclear as to whether the preceding sentence relates to the original or updated guidance. Anyway, the updated guidance is for 890-920kt of ilmenite, 65-70kt of zircon and 7-8kt of rutile at cash operating costs per tonne of finished product of US$131-141/t (previously: 855-1,045kt ilmenite, 63-77kt zircon and 7-9kt rutile at US$127-155/t).

Given the production numbers, we were surprised to see shipments down 9%. According to Kenmare, this was due to an ilmenite shipment being loaded over the period end and therefore not being reflected in the Q3 2016 shipment figures. We were pleased to learn that closing stock of finished products fell to 214.9kt (Q2 2016: 230.1kt), including 60kt being held for a customer that has been “subject to an advanced payment”.

PM

Meanwhile, the company has agreed higher sulphate ilmenite prices for H2 2016 with contracted customers (where pricing is set on a 6-monthly basis). Sulphate ilmenite demand saw “good improvement” in Q3 2016, with increased Chinese activity as a result of strong pigment production and ongoing curtailment of Chinese domestic ilmenite production. Kenmare expects supply to continue to tighten, and sees the prospect of an increase in its average received ilmenite price for 2017.
